speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: SCENE II. The same. The DUKE's palace.

speaker: LAUNCE
text_entry: Enter DUKE and THURIO

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Sir Thurio, fear not but that she will love you,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Now Valentine is banish'd from her sight.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Since his exile she hath despised me most,

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Forsworn my company and rail'd at me,

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: That I am desperate of obtaining her.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: This weak impress of love is as a figure

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Trenched in ice, which with an hour's heat

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Dissolves to water and doth lose his form.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: A little time will melt her frozen thoughts

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And worthless Valentine shall be forgot.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Enter PROTEUS

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: How now, Sir Proteus! Is your countryman

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: According to our proclamation gone?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Gone, my good lord.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: My daughter takes his going grievously.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: A little time, my lord, will kill that grief.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: So I believe; but Thurio thinks not so.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Proteus, the good conceit I hold of thee--

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: For thou hast shown some sign of good desert--

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Makes me the better to confer with thee.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Longer than I prove loyal to your grace

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Let me not live to look upon your grace.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Thou know'st how willingly I would effect

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: The match between Sir Thurio and my daughter.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: I do, my lord.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And also, I think, thou art not ignorant

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: How she opposes her against my will

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: She did, my lord, when Valentine was here.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Ay, and perversely she persevers so.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: What might we do to make the girl forget

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: The love of Valentine and love Sir Thurio?

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: The best way is to slander Valentine

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: With falsehood, cowardice and poor descent,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Three things that women highly hold in hate.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Ay, but she'll think that it is spoke in hate.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Ay, if his enemy deliver it:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Therefore it must with circumstance be spoken

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: By one whom she esteemeth as his friend.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Then you must undertake to slander him.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And that, my lord, I shall be loath to do:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: 'Tis an ill office for a gentleman,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Especially against his very friend.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Where your good word cannot advantage him,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Your slander never can endamage him;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Therefore the office is indifferent,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Being entreated to it by your friend.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: You have prevail'd, my lord; if I can do it

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: By ought that I can speak in his dispraise,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: She shall not long continue love to him.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But say this weed her love from Valentine,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: It follows not that she will love Sir Thurio.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Therefore, as you unwind her love from him,

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Lest it should ravel and be good to none,

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: You must provide to bottom it on me;

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Which must be done by praising me as much

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: As you in worth dispraise Sir Valentine.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And, Proteus, we dare trust you in this kind,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Because we know, on Valentine's report,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: You are already Love's firm votary

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And cannot soon revolt and change your mind.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Upon this warrant shall you have access

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Where you with Silvia may confer at large;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: For she is lumpish, heavy, melancholy,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: And, for your friend's sake, will be glad of you;

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Where you may temper her by your persuasion

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: To hate young Valentine and love my friend.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: As much as I can do, I will effect:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: But you, Sir Thurio, are not sharp enough;

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: You must lay lime to tangle her desires

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: By wailful sonnets, whose composed rhymes

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Should be full-fraught with serviceable vows.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Ay,

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Much is the force of heaven-bred poesy.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Say that upon the altar of her beauty

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: You sacrifice your tears, your sighs, your heart:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Write till your ink be dry, and with your tears

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Moist it again, and frame some feeling line

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: That may discover such integrity:

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: For Orpheus' lute was strung with poets' sinews,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Whose golden touch could soften steel and stones,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Make tigers tame and huge leviathans

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Forsake unsounded deeps to dance on sands.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: After your dire-lamenting elegies,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Visit by night your lady's chamber-window

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: With some sweet concert; to their instruments

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Tune a deploring dump: the night's dead silence

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: Will well become such sweet-complaining grievance.

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: This, or else nothing, will inherit her.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: This discipline shows thou hast been in love.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: And thy advice this night I'll put in practise.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Therefore, sweet Proteus, my direction-giver,

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: Let us into the city presently

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: To sort some gentlemen well skill'd in music.

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: I have a sonnet that will serve the turn

speaker: THURIO
text_entry: To give the onset to thy good advice.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: About it, gentlemen!

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: We'll wait upon your grace till after supper,

speaker: PROTEUS
text_entry: And afterward determine our proceedings.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Even now about it! I will pardon you.

speaker: DUKE
text_entry: Exeunt
